WRITING.TITLE: The body of an elite cricketer

WRITING.TEXT: Hard to argue, but Mr Cricket's cover drive was a thing of beauty too
A fine finish for the goal, and could have had a second assist. He's still dropping deep to get the ball, but he looks a constant threat, even if he hasn't taken every chance that's come his way.
Has Dharmasena just found a new way to check for no balls he's not watching out for?
I'm sure all the 14-year-olds will be very impressed.
'Smashed! ... fielded.' Is it just me, or is Heals getting worse?
At least they throw them underarm.
Commentary box cam? You mean we have to SEE them now too??

Have you considered booking a match break (hotel room + ticket) through Thomas Cook?
I recently travelled to the UK from Australia, and like you I had a small window of opportunity to catch a game. As luck would have it, that meant the City match.
The membership ballot was my main official avenue for tickets, but I wouldn't know for sure if I'd succeeded until relatively soon before the game.
I ended up booking through Thomas Cook, and though it was certainly an expensive option for seats in the NW quadrant at OT, at least I could be certain I'd secured tickets.
Note they apparently don't let customers outside the EU book these tickets any more, but a friend was able to book from the UK on my behalf and use my name as the actual guest for the hotel room and ticket.
I bet you're fun at parties.
Linesman flags a foul throw for lifting the foot. We really are in pre-season

WRITING.TITLE: But... how did I die?
(Article) Unpacking the genius of Kendrick Lamar's To Pimp A Butterfly

WRITING.TEXT:
It was a great experience, actually! The ground was soft enough to feel natural and the ball rolled true, which you can't say about most park grounds. It bounces a little higher in the field, but that's easy to get used to.
The only problem is, on a hot day the ground gets very, very hot. The rubber pellets used to bed the artificial turf absorb the heat from the sun and throw it right back at you. It can be sweaty work.

WRITING.TITLE: When someone tried to film Father John Misty's concert at the Sydney Opera House, he grabbed their phone and did it for them. Twice.
Has anyone played cricket on a synthetic outfield?
WRITING.TEXT:
My cricket club starts the season this weekend with a match on an entirely synthetic ground - that's outfield included, not just the pitch as we're used to here in Australia. It's something that happens far more often in the football codes.
Does anyone have experience playing on synthetic outfields? What should we expect? Any tips appreciated, as it's sure to be quite the change.

Michael Cockerill, who wrote this piece, was writing as Associate Editor on FFA's official site from 2012-14.
Not much of a surprise he's taking his former employer's side, even if under the sheen of 'independence' at another publication...
This is all your fault.
